Award.AwardTitle: OSA Biomedical Optics: Translating Biomedical Optics from the Scientific Bench to Clinical Practice Research Dissemination Congress, Ft. Lauderdale, Florida

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Quarles, Greg
Proposal Number: 1638444
Title: OSA BIOMEDICAL CONGRESSS

ABSTRACT:

The high level of technical development in biomedical optics, biophotonics, and the brain is drawing new researchers into the field from diverse disciplines ranging from chemistry and genetics, to laser optics and neurosurgery. OSA has identified the urgent need for a forum where these researchers can come together and discuss these areas at many levels.

This meeting will provide a forum for presentation of new research results and will stimulate new ideas and collaborations that will provide visionary direction for future projects. In addition this meeting will provide an opportunity for students, trainees and young investigators to present their work, and to hear and network with internationally-renowned invited speakers

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF provided the $49,500 grant funds to support The Biomedical Optics: Translating Biomedical Optics from the Scientific Bench to Clinical Practice Research Dissemination Congress, Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, by supplementing the registration and travel costs of 60 participants, including students, early career professionals and invited speakers, and supporting other meeting related costs. OSA was able to recruit a diverse group of invited speakers to share pioneering work thus enriching the scientific content of the event for all participants. Critical support was provided by NSF to assist in reduction of registration fees to increase participation and enhance diversity of students and early career professionals. The 2016 Biomedical Optics Congress was held 25-28 April 2016, and attended by 423 participants.

 

The congress included the following topical meetings: Cancer Imaging and Therapy (Cancer), Clinical and Translational Biophotonics (Translational), Optics and the Brain (Brain), and Optical Tomography and Spectroscopy (OTS). The Cancer conference focused on optical methods in cancer, centered on imaging and treatment of cancer. The meeting presented topics on the molecular and cellular level, such as reporters and theranostics; on the tissue and pre-clinical (animal) level, such as pathology methods and advances in imaging of tumor models; and on human tissue and living human subjects, when specifically dealing with cancer. The Translational conference focused on research that has demonstrated human clinical applications, such as bioimaging or biosensing of human tissue specimens, first-to-human investigations of new optical imaging technologies for disease detection, diagnosis, or monitoring, clinical studies, and larger clinical trials. The Brain meeting presented an important, highly interdisciplinary area of research that combines broad aspects of neuroscience, biology, medicine, physics, chemistry and engineering. This conference brought together researchers working in all aspects of optics in the brain and served as a forum for discussion of existing and emerging techniques as well as future directions capable of shedding new light on the healthy and diseased brain. The OTS meeting focused on new developments in tomographic imaging technology in the fields of diffuse optical tomography (DOT), optical coherence tomography (OCT), photoacoustic tomography (PAT), as well as on new developments in spectroscopic technologies.

 

This grant has had a number of impacts beyond the meeting itself. The meeting provided exposure to a very active multidisciplinary field with direct applications today, allowing students to see how their educational training can lead to the benefits for society. Such exposure helps motivate students to pursue careers in science with resultant benefits to scientific knowledge and technical benefits to mankind. The topical meetings within the congress gave an opportunity to network with colleagues within the participant’s specific field and to learn more about other fields. With 423 attendees gathering, this meeting created a unique and exceptional opportunity for intellectually stimulating one-on-one interactions with leaders and colleagues. Additionally, the meeting itself helped advance the field through sharing of results, methods, inspiring of new ideas, and initiation of collaborations. The interdisciplinary nature of the congress provided cross fertilization of concepts and techniques between fields with the resulting synergies obtained from such interactions.
